sen.j: 御節料理（おせちりょうり）は、節日（節句）に作られる料理。
sen.e: Osechi-ryori is originally a term used to refer to foods prepared for Sechinichi or Sekku (seasonal festivals).
Osechi-ryori is originally a term used in reference to foods prepared for Sechinichi or Sekku (seasonal festivals).
Osechi-ryori is originally a term used in reference to foods prepared for Sechinichi or Sekku (seasonal festivals).

sen.j: 特に、正月に備えて年明けまでに用意されるお祝いの料理（献立）を指す。
sen.e: It particularly refers to festival foods (menu) prepared by the New Year's Eve for the New Year's holidays.
Specifically, it refers to festival foods (menus) prepared by New Year's Eve for the New Year's holidays.
Specifically, it refers to festival foods (menus) prepared by New Year's Eve for the New Year's holidays.

sen.j: 単におせちともいう。
sen.e: Osechi-ryori is also called simply as Osechi.
Osechi-ryori is also called simply Osechi.
Osechi-ryori is also called simply Osechi.

sen.j: 正月料理。
sen.e: Foods for the New Year's holidays
Foods for the New Year's holidays

sen.j: 現代では保存がきく作り置きの正月の料理となっている。
sen.e: Nowadays, osechi dishes are foods for the New Year's holidays, which can last a couple of days in the refrigerator or at cool room temperature.
Nowadays, osechi dishes are foods for the New Year's holidays, which can last a couple of days in the refrigerator or at a cool room temperature.

sen.j: これは、「神様をお迎えした新年に台所を騒がせてはならない」、という考えによるものである。
sen.e: This reflects a belief that "the kitchen must be kept quiet during the New Year's holidays to invite gods"
This reflects the belief that "the kitchen must be kept quiet during New Year's holidays to invite gods."
This reflects the belief that "the kitchen must be kept quiet during New Year's holidays to invite gods."

sen.j: 転じて、煮しめた保存食により女性が正月三が日に休めるように、とも言われる。
sen.e: It is also said that another purpose of the custom is to allow women to take rest during the New Year's holidays by means of the simmered preserved foods.
It is also said that another purpose of the custom is to allow women to rest during the New Year's holidays by means of the simmered, preserved foods.
It is also said that another purpose of the custom is to allow women to rest during the New Year's holidays by means of the simmered, preserved foods.

sen.j: 台所を騒がせず、女性を休めることも目的であるため、家庭での手作りに特別な価値があるわけではない。
sen.e: Because the purpose is to keep the kitchen quiet and to allow women to take rest, osechi dishes need not necessarily be hand-made.
Because the purpose is to keep the kitchen quiet and allow women to rest, osechi dishes don't necessarily have to be hand-made.
Because the purpose is to keep the kitchen quiet and allow women to rest, osechi dishes don't necessarily have to be hand-made.

sen.j: したがって近年ではデパートや料亭などのおせち料理が購入されることがある。
sen.e: Accordingly, osechi dishes are sometimes purchased at department stores or restaurants recently.
Accordingly, osechi dishes are now sometimes purchased at department stores or restaurants.
Accordingly, osechi dishes are now sometimes purchased at department stores or restaurants.

sen.j: 本来は「年迎え」の膳として、大晦日に食べるものであった。
sen.e: Osechi dishes were originally foods eaten on the New Year's Eve to invite the New Year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Originally, osechi dishes were eaten on New Year's Eve to invite the new year.
Originally, osechi dishes were eaten on New Year's Eve to invite the new year.

sen.j: 現在ではほとんどの地方で元日以降に食べるのが普通である。
sen.e: Nowadays, however, they are commonly eaten on and after the New Year's Day in almost all the regions in Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Today, however, they're commonly eaten on and after New Year's Day in nearly every region of Japan.
Today, however, they're commonly eaten on and after New Year's Day in nearly every region of Japan.

sen.j: ただし、北海道など一部の地方には、かつての名残りで大晦日に食べる風習が残っている。
sen.e: In some part of Japan, such as Hokkaido, however, osechi dishes are still eaten on the New Year's Eve, following the old custom.
However, in some parts of Japan, such as Hokkaido, osechi dishes are still eaten on New Year's Eve, following the old custom.
However, in some parts of Japan, such as Hokkaido, osechi dishes are still eaten on New Year's Eve, following the old custom.

sen.j: 正月元日（1月1日）も、昔から、山に帰った田の神を呼び戻すために祝われる重要な節日とされていた。
sen.e: Since ancient times, the New Year's Day (January 1) has been celebrated as an important seasonal festival to bring back the god of paddy field who had returned to his mountain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Since ancient times, New Year's Day (January 1) has been celebrated as an important seasonal festival to bring back the god of paddy fields, who had returned to his mountain.
Since ancient times, New Year's Day (January 1) has been celebrated as an important seasonal festival to bring back the god of paddy fields, who had returned to his mountain.

sen.j: ある時、凶作によって食料が枯渇し、正月に炊飯する為の竈から煙が上がらないのを高殿に昇った仁徳天皇が見つけた。
sen.e: Once upon a time, when Emperor NINTOKU went up to the tower of his palace on the New Year's Day, he notices that there was no smoke rising up from kitchen chimneys of houses because of shortage of foods due to bad harvest.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Once upon a time, when Emperor NINTOKU went up to the tower of his palace on New Year's Day, he noticed that there was no smoke rising up from the kitchen chimneys of houses because of shortage of foods due to a bad harvest.

Once upon a time, when Emperor NINTOKU went up to the tower of his palace on New Year's Day, he noticed that there was no smoke rising up from the kitchen chimneys of houses because of shortage of foods due to a bad harvest.

sen.j: 仁徳天皇は、心を痛め、「正月に民達の竈から煙の上らない年は免税とする」と言った。
sen.e: He was shocked by the scene and said "I will not levy taxes in the year when smoke does not rise up from kitchen chimneys of houses on the New Year's Day.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He was shocked by the scene and said, "I will not levy taxes in the year when smoke does not rise up from the kitchen chimneys of houses on New Year's Day."
He was shocked by the scene and said, "I will not levy taxes in the year when smoke does not rise up from the kitchen chimneys of houses on New Year's Day."

sen.j: このため、税逃がれ目的で毎年の正月は竈を休ませる日となった。
sen.e: Accordingly, people decided not to cook on the New Year's Day in order to avoid taxes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Accordingly, people decided not to cook on New Year's Day in order to avoid taxes.
Accordingly, people decided not to cook on New Year's Day in order to avoid taxes.

sen.j: その後も免税措置は撤回せず、仁徳天皇の御殿は雨漏りがするほど酷い状況であったという。
sen.e: It is said that Emperor NINTOKU did not revoke the tax exemption policy even though he could not repair his palace due to shortage of income.
It is said that Emperor NINTOKU did not revoke the tax exemption policy even though he couldn't repair his palace due to the shortage of income.
It is said that Emperor NINTOKU did not revoke the tax exemption policy even though he couldn't repair his palace due to the shortage of income.

sen.j: 現在では、一般に祝う風習のある節日は正月のみとなった。
sen.e: Nowadays, the New Year's Day is the only seasonal festival which is commonly celebrated in Japan.
Nowadays, New Year's Day is the only seasonal festival that is commonly celebrated in Japan.
Nowadays, New Year's Day is the only seasonal festival that is commonly celebrated in Japan.

sen.j: このため、御節料理とは、前年の大晦日までに作られる、翌年の正月のための料理（正月料理）のみを指すようになった。
sen.e: Therefore, today's osechi-ryori only refers to the foods for the New Year's Day prepared by the New Year's Eve (foods for the New Year's holidays).
Therefore, today's osechi-ryori only refers to the foods for New Year's Day that are prepared by New Year's Eve (foods for the New Year's holidays).
Therefore, today's osechi-ryori only refers to the foods for New Year's Day that are prepared by New Year's Eve (foods for the New Year's holidays).

sen.j: 「御節」とは、中国大陸から伝わった暦上の節目、季節の変わり目などにあたる節日（せちにち、節句）のことを指す。
sen.e: Osechi is originally a term used to refer to Sechinichi or Sekku (seasonal festivals) corresponding to special occasions on calendar, the change of seasons, etc., which were imported from the Chinese continent.

Osechi was originally a term used in reference to Sechinichi or Sekku (seasonal festivals) corresponding to special occasions on the calendar, the change of seasons, etc., which were imported from the Chinese continent.

Osechi was originally a term used in reference to Sechinichi or Sekku (seasonal festivals) corresponding to special occasions on the calendar, the change of seasons, etc., which were imported from the Chinese continent.

sen.j: 節日には祝事を行い、祝い膳がしつらえられた。
sen.e: On the seasonal festivals, festival foods were prepared.
For the seasonal events, festival foods were prepared.
For the seasonal events, festival foods were prepared.

sen.j: このとき作られるめでたい料理が、「御節料理」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Festival foods prepared for these occasions were called as osechi-ryori.
The festival foods prepared for these occasions were called osechi-ryori.
The festival foods prepared for these occasions were called osechi-ryori.

sen.j: 御節料理の基本は、お屠蘇、祝い肴三種（三つ肴）、雑煮、煮しめである。
sen.e: The basic osechi-ryori consists of Otoso, Iwaizakana-sanshu (Mitsu-zakana), Zoni, and Nishime.
The basic osechi-ryori consists of Otoso, Iwaizakana-sanshu (Mitsu-zakana), Zoni and Nishime.
The basic osechi-ryori consists of Otoso, Iwaizakana-sanshu (Mitsu-zakana), Zoni and Nishime.

sen.j: 地方により、三つ肴、雑煮、煮しめの内容は異なる。
sen.e: The contents of the mitsu-zakana, the zoni, and the nishime vary depending on the region.
The contents of the mitsu-zakana, the zoni and the nishime vary according to the region.
The contents of the mitsu-zakana, the zoni and the nishime vary according to the region.

sen.j: このうち、三つ肴と煮しめは、重箱に詰めて供される。
sen.e: Out of these, the mitsu-zakana and the nishime are served in a nest of lacquered boxes.
Out of these, the mitsu-zakana and nishime are served in nests of lacquered boxes.
Out of these, the mitsu-zakana and nishime are served in nests of lacquered boxes.

sen.j: 一般的には、御節料理とは、献立すべてを指すのではなく、重箱詰めされた料理のみを指す。
sen.e: The term osechi-ryori commonly refers only to the foods packed in the nest of lacquered boxes rather than the whole menu.
The term "osechi-ryori" commonly refers only to the foods packed in a nest of lacquered boxes instead of referring to the entire menu.
The term "osechi-ryori" commonly refers only to the foods packed in a nest of lacquered boxes instead of referring to the entire menu.

sen.j: 重箱に詰めるのは、めでたさを「重ねる」という意味で縁起をかついだものである（同様の意味合いから、雑煮もおかわりをするのが良いとされている）。
sen.e: The style of packing foods in a nest of lacquered boxes represents multi-layered happiness (for the same reason, it is said that you should ask for refill when you eat zoni).
The style of packing foods in nests of lacquered boxes represents multilayered happiness (for the same reason, it is said that one should ask for a refill when eating zoni).
The style of packing foods in nests of lacquered boxes represents multilayered happiness (for the same reason, it is said that one should ask for a refill when eating zoni).

sen.j: 一つ一つの料理は、火を通したり干したり、あるいは酢に漬けたり味を濃くするなど、日持ちする物が多い。
sen.e: Many of osechi dishes can last a couple of days in the refrigerator or at cool room temperature because they have been heated, dried, vinegared, or flavored strongly.
Many osechi dishes can last a couple of days in the refrigerator or at a cool room temperature because they've been heated, dried, vinegared or heavily flavored.
Many osechi dishes can last a couple of days in the refrigerator or at a cool room temperature because they've been heated, dried, vinegared or heavily flavored.

sen.j: これは、火の神である荒神を怒らせないため、正月に台所で火を使うことを避けるという平安時代後期からの風習により、正月には台所仕事をしないからである。
sen.e: This is because the kitchen is not used during the New Year's holidays due to a custom established in the late Heian period in which use of fire is avoided in the kitchen during the New Year's holidays so as not to anger Kojin, or the god of fire.

This is because the kitchen isn't used during the New Year's holidays due to a custom established in the late Heian period, in which the use of fire is avoided in the kitchen during the New Year's holidays so as not to anger Kojin, the god of fire.

This is because the kitchen isn't used during the New Year's holidays due to a custom established in the late Heian period, in which the use of fire is avoided in the kitchen during the New Year's holidays so as not to anger Kojin, the god of fire.

sen.j: 実際には、女性を正月位は休ませるためという意味合いもある。
sen.e: In fact, another purpose of the custom is to allow busy women to take rest during the New Year's holidays.
In fact, another purpose of the custom is to allow busy women to rest during the New Year's holidays.
In fact, another purpose of the custom is to allow busy women to rest during the New Year's holidays.

sen.j: 現在では、食品の保存技術も進んだため、生ものや珍味など、多種多様な料理を重箱に詰めて供することも多い。
sen.e: Nowadays, thanks to advancements in food preservation technology, a variety of foods, such as perishables and costly delicacies, are also frequently served in the nest of lacquered boxes.
Nowadays, thanks to advancements in food preservation technology, various foods, such as perishables and costly delicacies, are also frequently served in nests of lacquered boxes.
Nowadays, thanks to advancements in food preservation technology, various foods, such as perishables and costly delicacies, are also frequently served in nests of lacquered boxes.

sen.j: また、お節料理を自宅で作らずに既成の詰め合わせのお節料理を、食料品店、百貨店、インターネット上の店舗その他で買い求める人々も増えている。
sen.e: Furthermore, an increasing number of people are purchasing ready-made packed osechi dishes at grocery stores, department stores, or stores on the Internet rather than preparing them at home.
Furthermore, people increasingly purchase ready-made packed osechi dishes at grocery stores and department stores, or from Internet sites, instead of preparing them at home.
Furthermore, people increasingly purchase ready-made packed osechi dishes at grocery stores and department stores, or from Internet sites, instead of preparing them at home.

sen.j: 更に、首都圏の113家庭を対象とした調査では、2004年頃から正月だからといって殊更御節料理にとらわれない人も現れているようである。
sen.e: In addition, according to a survey conducted on 113 households in the metropolitan area, it seems that people who do not eat osechi dishes on the New Year's holidays have been starting to appear around 2004.

Additionally, according to a survey conducted on 113 households in the metropolitan area, it seems that, starting around 2004, there have been people who don't eat osechi dishes during the New Year's holidays.

sen.j: 正月の祝に欠かせない三種類の料理である。
sen.e: Iwaizakana-sanshu is a term used to refer to three kinds of indispensable osechi dishes to celebrate the New Year's Day..
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The term "iwaizakana-sanshu" is used in reference to three kinds of indispensable osechi dishes for the celebration of New Year's Day.
The term "iwaizakana-sanshu" is used in reference to three kinds of indispensable osechi dishes for the celebration of New Year's Day.

sen.j: 祝い肴と餅を揃えれば最低限の正月の祝いができる。
sen.e: When Mochi (rice cake) is available in addition to the iwaizakana, you can celebrate the New Year's Day.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When mochi (rice cake) is available in addition to the iwaizakana, one can celebrate New Year's Day.
When mochi (rice cake) is available in addition to the iwaizakana, one can celebrate New Year's Day.

sen.j: 逆に、どんなに贅沢な料理を揃えても、祝い肴がないと正月の祝い膳の体裁が整わない。
sen.e: Conversely, without the iwaizakana, even with other expensive foods, you cannot celebrate the New Year's Day.
Conversely, without the iwaizakana, even with other expensive foods, one can't celebrate New Year's Day.
Conversely, without the iwaizakana, even with other expensive foods, the festive table for celebrating New Year's Day cannot be completed.
sen.cmt: 文意に合うように変えました。

sen.j: 「三つ肴」とも言われる。

sen.j: 田作り（たづくり）
sen.e: Tazukuri
Tazukuri
Tazukuri

sen.j: ごまめ（カタクチイワシの稚魚）を醤油風味の飴炊きにしたもの。
sen.e: Tazukuri is a term used to refer to Gomame (small sardines) that have been dried and then finished in a sweet sauce of sugar, mirin, soy sauce, and sake.
Tazukuri is a term used in reference to Gomame (small sardines) that have been dried and then finished in a sweet sauce of sugar, mirin, soy sauce and sake.
Tazukuri is a term used in reference to Gomame (small sardines) that have been dried and then finished in a sweet sauce of sugar, mirin, soy sauce and sake.

sen.j: 田畑の高級肥料としてイワシが使われていた事から豊作を願って食べられた。
sen.e: Tazukuri has been eaten to pray for a good harvest because sardines were used as useful fertilizer for plowlands.
Tazukuri has been eaten to pray for a good harvest because sardines were employed as a useful fertilizer for plowed lands.
Tazukuri has been eaten to pray for a good harvest because sardines were employed as a useful fertilizer for plowed lands.

sen.j: 数の子（かずのこ）

sen.j: 魚卵の数が多いことから子孫繁栄を願って食べられた。
sen.e: Kazunoko has been eaten to pray for the prosperity of descendants because the number of roe is large.
Kazunoko has traditionally been eaten to pray for the prosperity of descendants, because the number of roe is large.

sen.j: 黒豆（くろまめ）
sen.e: Kuromame (Simmered black beans)
Kuromame (simmered black beans)
Kuromame (simmered black beans)

sen.j: 黒には魔よけの力が有るとされていたので、まめ（勤勉）に働き、まめ（健康）に暮らせることを願って食べられた。
sen.e: Kuromame has been eaten to be able to work hard and lead a healthy life because it was said that its black color has an effect of charming against evil spirits.
Kuromame has been eaten to encourage the ability to work hard and lead a healthy life, because it was said that its black color has the effect of charming evil spirits.

Kuromame has been eaten to encourage the ability to work hard and lead a healthy life ("mame" in Japanese means hard-working and good health), because it was said that its black color has the effect of charming evil spirits.

sen.j: たたきゴボウ
sen.e: Tataki-gobo (Burdock roots that have been whacked and dressed with a sesame dressing)

sen.j: 形や色が豊作のときに飛んでくると伝えられている黒い瑞鳥を連想させる事から豊作を願って食べられた。
sen.e: Tataki-gobo has been eaten to pray for a good harvest because its shape and color are similar to those of a black auspicious bird that is said to come flying down when a good harvest is expected.

sen.j: 祝儀用としてめでたい彩りから。

Kohaku-kamaboko has been eaten because red and white are colors representing happiness.

sen.j: 元は神饌の赤米、白米を模した物。

sen.j: 伊達巻
sen.e: Date-maki (Sweet egg omelet made from eggs, hanpen (marshmallow like fish cake), and sugar)
Date-maki (sweet egg omelet made from eggs, hanpen (marshmallow-like fish cake) and sugar)
Date-maki (sweet egg omelet made from eggs, hanpen (marshmallow-like fish cake) and sugar)

sen.j: 「伊達」の由来は華やかさ派手さを表す言葉で伊達政宗の派手好きに由来することの他、諸説ある。
sen.e: Date is a term used to express sportiness; it is said that the term is originated from Masamune DATE's attention-getting style, etc.
The term "date" is used to express sportiness; it is said that this term originated from Masamune DATE's attention-getting style, etc.
The term "date" is used to express gorgeousness; it is said that this term originated from Masamune DATE's attention-getting style, etc.

sen.j: 見た目の豪華さで定番となる。
sen.e: Date-maki is indispensable because of its sportiness.
Date-maki is indispensable because of its sportiness.
Date-maki is indispensable because of its gorgeous appearance.

sen.j: 巻き物（書物）に似た形から、知識が増える事を願う縁起物。
sen.e: Furthermore, date-maki has been eaten also to pray for success in academic fields because of its appearance similar to that of a rolled book.

sen.j: 関西風の御節では「だし巻き卵」が代わりに入っていることが多い。
sen.e: According to the kansai style, a plain rolled omelet is often served instead of the date-maki.

sen.j: クリ金団（くりきんとん）
sen.e: Kuri-kinton (Mashed sweet potato with sweet chestnuts)

Kuri-kinton (mashed sweet potatoes with sweet chestnuts)

sen.j: 「金団」とは黄金の団子という意味（金の布団の意味とする地方もある）。
sen.e: Kinton is a term used to refer to a gold-colored dumpling (it may mean a golden mattress in some regions).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The term "kinton" is used in reference to a gold-colored dumpling (in some regions it may mean a golden mattress).
The term "kinton" is used in reference to a gold-colored dumpling (in some regions it may mean a golden mattress).

sen.j: 見た目の色合いが豪華で金塊のように見えるところから定番となる。
sen.e: Kuri-kinton is indispensable because it looks like a gold ingot due to its colorful and gorgeous appearance.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kuri-kinton is indispensable because it looks like a gold ingot due to its colorful, gorgeous appearance.

sen.j: 元は神饌。

sen.j: ひげが長く腰が曲がっている様子が老人を連想させる事から長寿を祈願したもの。
sen.e: Ebi-no-yakimono has been eaten to pray for a long life because the shape of a lobster with its long antennas and curved waist is similar to that of an aged person.

sen.j: イセエビを使うことが多かったが、高価である為、クルマエビなどが使用されている。

sen.j: 鰻登りから出世を祈願。
sen.e: Unagi-no-yakimono has been eaten to pray for promotion because eels will, no matter how steep the rapids are or how little water there is, manage to swim further upstream.

sen.e: Renkon has been eaten to pray for a life without obstacles because lotus roots have many through-holes which allow people to see the other side without obstacles.
Renkon has been eaten to pray for a life without obstacles. because lotus roots have many through-holes which allow one to see through to the other side without obstacles.

sen.e: Satoimo has been eaten to pray for the prosperity of descendants because a parent taro is commonly accompanied by many small child taros.
Satoimo has been eaten to pray for the prosperity of descendants because a parent taro is commonly accompanied by many small, child taros.

sen.j: また、漢字の八に「末広がり」の意味をかけて。
sen.e: In addition, the term Yatsugashira literally means "eight heads", and eight is a lucky number in Japan.
Additionally, the term "yatsugashira" literally means "eight heads," and eight is a lucky number in Japan.

sen.j: 昆布
sen.e: Konbu (Kelps)
Konbu (kelp)
Konbu (kelp)

sen.j: 伝統的な御節料理の重詰めには五段重を使うが、近年では省略され三段重が利用される場合が多い。
sen.e: While traditional osechi dishes have been packed in five-layered lacquered boxes, simplified three-layered lacquered boxes are also increasingly coming into use recently.
While traditional osechi dishes have been packed in five-layer lacquered boxes, recently simplified three-layer lacquered boxes have come into use.
While traditional osechi dishes have been packed in five-layer lacquered boxes, recently simplified three-layer lacquered boxes have come into use.

sen.j: 重箱に詰めるのは、めでたさを「重ねる」という意味で縁起をかついだものである（同様の意味合いから、雑煮もおかわりをするのが良いとされている）。
sen.e: The style of packing foods in a nest of lacquered boxes represents multi-layered happiness (for the same reason, it is said that you should ask for refill when you eat zoni).
The style of packing foods in nests of lacquered boxes represents multilayer happiness (for the same reason, it is said that one should ask for a refill when eating zoni).
The style of packing foods in nests of lacquered boxes represents multilayer happiness (for the same reason, it is said that one should ask for a refill when eating zoni).

sen.j: 重箱は上から順に一の重、二の重、三の重、与の重、五の重と数える。
sen.e: The lacquered boxes are called as ichi-no-ju (the first box), ni-no-ju (the second box), san-no-ju (the third box), yo (与) -no-ju (the fourth box), and go-no-ju (the fifth box) in descending order.
The lacquered boxes are called ichi-no-ju (the first box), ni-no-ju (the second box), san-no-ju (the third box), yo (与) -no-ju (the fourth box) and go-no-ju (the fifth box), in descending order.
The lacquered boxes are called ichi-no-ju (the first box), ni-no-ju (the second box), san-no-ju (the third box), yo (与) -no-ju (the fourth box) and go-no-ju (the fifth box), from the top.
sen.cmt: 「上から」＝from the topと変えました。

sen.j: 四段目が与の重（よのじゅう）と呼ばれるのは四（し）が死を連想させ縁起が悪いと考えられているためである。
sen.e: The yo (与) -no-ju (the fourth box) is written as "与" instead of "四" because the pronunciation of "四" is the same as that of "死 (death)".
The yo (与) -no-ju (the fourth box) is written as "与" instead of "四," because the pronunciation of "四" is the same as that of "死 (death)."
The yo (与) -no-ju (the fourth box) is written as "与" instead of "四," because the pronunciation of "四" is the same as that of "死 (death)."

sen.j: 詰め方は地域や家風によっても異なるがおおむね以下のようになっている。
sen.e: Although the order may vary depending on the region or the house, osechi dishes are commonly packed as follows.
Although the order may vary depending on the region or the house, osechi dishes are commonly packed as follows:
Although the order may vary depending on the region or the house, osechi dishes are commonly packed as follows:

sen.j: なお、四段重が正式であるといわれる場合もある。
sen.e: Four-box style is sometimes said to be formal.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The four-box style is sometimes said to be formal.
The four-box style is sometimes said to be formal.

sen.j: これは控えの重（五の重）を省略した形である。
sen.e: However, the four-box style is a simplified variation of the five-box style by omitting the fifth box (the stand-by box)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the four-box style is a simplified variation of the five-box style, from which the fifth box (the stand-by box) is omitted.
However, the four-box style is a simplified variation of the five-box style, from which the fifth box (the stand-by box) is omitted.
